urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNN3-RTWS-G17W-00000-00'HISTORY' BURNS AT GALLIPOLI1994-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:27ZLexisNexisPg. 3'HISTORY' BURNS AT GALLIPOLI

KEYWORD-HIT "History' burns at Gallipoli ANKARA: A fire chief died and five people were missing in a forest fire which has raged since yesterday through Turkey's Gelibolu (Gallipoli) peninsula. The area is famous for the Anzac and Allied campaign against the Turks in World War I. Governor Husnu Tuglu of Canakkale province said it was not immediately clear if any military cemeteries and war memorials were threatened. ""History is burning here and we are powerless to stop it,'' he said last night. The fire has consumed 2000 hectares of pine forest. A senior fire official died of asphyxiation and five men in a watchtower inside the burning area were missing. The fire swept through the Eceabat national park, covering the Kocadere area where Turks fought Australian and New Zealand troops in 1915-1916.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bushfire threatens northern homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SUE BAILEY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A BIG forest fire threatened homes, closed a highway and destroyed eight square kilometres of bushland in northern Tasmania yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> About 30 firefighters from 11 fire units were last night keeping a close watch on the fire south of Lefroy on the East Tamar.</p><p>At the height of the blaze a pall of smoke hung over Launceston's northern suburbs.</p><p> Paul Hodges, group officer with the Dalrymple group of brigades, said quick action by firefighters stopped the fire destroying any homes or farm property.</p><p> "There were no evacuations but a couple of houses were threatened though it was not a big problem," Mr Hodges said.</p><p> "There were a couple of times we thought we'd lost it but the proficiency of the volunteer firefighters won out.</p><p> "We used two bulldozers to set up fire breaks and that way we were able to save adjoining farmlands so it was mainly bush that was destroyed."</p><p> The Flinders Highway between Bell Bay and Bridport was closed for about four hours because of the blaze.</p><p> It is not known how the fire started.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier He was trapped. He had no place to go," Mrs Hiser said.</p><p> The 206L-1 model produced by Bell was widely used by law enforcement agencies, fire departments and television news crews.</p><p> About 1700 choppers produced in the 1980s came under scrutiny by pilots who complained the aircraft lost power in flight.</p><p> Federal regulators did not find any problems with the helicopter's fuel system design but sent a letter warning pilots to properly service the system.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FED: URGENT TRAINING NEEDED FOR FIREFIGHTERS IN INDONESIA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CANBERRA, Oct 24 AAP - Australian experts today called for urgent training for firefighters battling to contain forest and bush fires on the Indonesian islnd of Sumatra.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Out of Australia's $2 million assistance for the Indonesian forest fire crisis training and equipment for the teams should be the top priority, the federal government's overseas aid agency AusAID said.</p><p>"In southern Sumatra, where local ground firefighting operations were observed, the team reported an urgent need for training and basic equipment provision," AusAID said in a statement.</p><p> Two Australian aerial water-bombing planes have continued to fly sorties attacking fires in Lampung Province in southern Sumatra.</p><p> The planes have flown 332 successful sorties and dumped 972 tonnes of fire suppressant on the fires, the statement said.</p><p> At least six Indonesians have died of haze-related ailments and 40,000 others estimated to have been affected.</p><p> Timber and plantation companies have been blamed for starting the fires to clear their land.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4C90-0048-T200-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="173"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:44DX-H870-015H-93K3-00000-00<published>2001-02-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Flare sparks</p><p nitf:lede="true">police alert</p><p nitf:lede="true">POLICE and marine emergency services were placed on alert last night after the reported sighting of a distress flare near Granville Harbour on Tasmania's West Coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Police said the report was received about 9pm.</p><p>Fire rings</p><p>alarm bells</p><p>A FOREST fire on Eaglehawk Neck last night sparked a barrage of calls from as far away as Mt Nelson.</p><p> The blaze was visible from Hobart and created more panic in distant population centres than among locals. A Tasmania Fire Service spokesman said the blaze looked spectacular but was safe enough for most crews to leave the fire scene by 11pm.</p><p>Top jazz band</p><p>at the Gorge</p><p>INTERNATIONAL jazz band Natural Gas will make a special guest appearance at this year's A Night in the Gorge concert in Launceston on February 24.</p><p> It will support the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra and the Three Chinese Tenors.</p><p>Remanded on</p><p>theft charges</p><p>A MAN was remanded in custody after he appeared in court charged with the theft of $20,000 from a safe.</p><p> Nathan Charles Mills, 21, of no fixed address, appeared in the Burnie Magistrates Court yesterday charged with burglary and stealing.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata nitf:lede="true">Firefighters were today trying to control a forest fire near the Mt Buller ski resort.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But a Conservation, Forests and Lands fire-control officer said the fire had been halted and 50 firefighters were working hard to control it.</p><p>He said police had been asked to investigate the fire which burnt through about 40ha of inaccessible snow gum country yesterday and overnight.</p><p> The officer said it was likely the fire had been intentionally lit.</p><p> During the height of the blaze, there were fears for the Mt Buller resort 4km away, but heavy aerial bombing with chemicals slowed its progress.</p><p> The flames were finally checked as the night cooled.</p><p> Department firefighters also would watch nine other fires around the state after outbreaks yesterday.All were minor and under control, the officer said.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Torrid day of dust and flames</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A HAZE which hung over the metropolitan area yesterday was caused by strong north-westerly winds carrying dust from dry paddocks in the north.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The problem was more severe on parts of Eyre Peninsula.</p><p>Southern Yorke Peninsula was buffeted by winds of up to 50km/h which hampered Country Fire Service efforts to battle a fire which began at 12.30pm.</p><p> The blaze destroyed 200ha of scrub about 5km south of Warooka before it was contained by 60 firefighters late yesterday.</p><p> A 200sq m forest fire in the South-East was contained by Forestry SA firefighters and a CFS firebombing aircraft which dropped foam on the fire.</p><p> It began in a block of 1958 pines near Glencoe nursery at 4pm.</p><p> The CFS, Forestry SA and police were investigating the cause.</p><p> And two bomber aircraft helped CFS crews contain a grass fire near Mylor just before 4pm.</p><p> The cause of the blaze, which was contained to 250sq m, is not known.</p><p> Fire also blackened about 2ha of grassland behind O'Sullivan Beach Football Club late yesterday.</p><p> It was extinguished at 5.50pm by Metropolitan Fire Service crews.</p><p> The temperature in Adelaide peaked at 38.2 degrees at 2.24pm yesterday  making it the hottest March 17 on record.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Since the beginning of the dry season five months ago, more than 12,000 ha of forest have been destroyed by forest fires.</p><p> (VNA)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SH3-H0J0-0048-T1J4-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="188"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGC0-TXN5-R1V3-00000-00CHINA FACES THREAT FROM SOVIET FIRE1987-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:26ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1CHINA FACES THREAT FROM SOVIET FIRESource: Associated Press

BEIJING, Sunday: Chinese firefighters, exhausted from an 18-day battle with the nation's worst forest fire in decades, face a new threat from a major fire approaching from the Soviet Union, the official news agency Xinhua said today.

The news agency report from Hohhot, capital of China's Inner Mongolia, said north-westerly winds had pushed the Soviet fire another two kilometres toward the Chinese border, and it was now only eight kilometres from the border.

It said the fire has been slowed somewhat by low temperatures and light showers, but is likely to cross the 150-metre wide Ergun River dividing the two countries if the winds pick up.

Alongside these children, women, sick and old people will be given priority assistance."</p><p> Mr Downer said the grant to World Vision followed a recommendation from the Australian health assistance team sent to Indonesia by AusAID earlier this month.</p><p> He said the $300,000 formed part of the $2 million aid provided for forest fire and drought relief in Indonesia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-49V0-0048-T3T4-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="187"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. Australia today promised $1 million in drought aid for the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said 400,000 people faced starvation in Irian Jaya, which borders Papua New Guinea where 500,000 people are also at risk because of severe drought.</p><p>"A UN disaster assessment team which recently visited the worst affected areas found Irian Jaya is on the verge of famine," Mr Downer said in a statement.</p><p> "Smoke from forest fires is severely restricting flights carrying food into the affected regions.</p><p> "The UNDAC team also reported that local water supplies are drying out and the little water left is polluted resulting in more people suffering diarrhoea, scabies and respiratory tract infections."</p><p> Mr Downer said half of Australia's donation would go to a United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA) appeal and the other half to the International Committee of the Red Cross.</p><p> Australia has already donated $7 million towards drought relief in Papua New Guinea, while $3 million has now been committed to Indonesia for drought and forest fire assistance.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-41T0-0048-T44X-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="191"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7M-CWG0-TXN5-R2FN-00000-00BRIEFS1990-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:26ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 8BRIEFS

HUGE BLAST AT SOVIET ARMY BASE

PRAGUE, Wednesday: A powerful explosion ripped through a Soviet military area in south-east Czechoslovakia yesterday and Prague's Defence Ministry said Soviet troops had blown up an ammunition dump in violation of regulations.

"The explosion was a result of a breach of all possible regulations," a Defence Ministry spokesman said after the blast was reported by Czechoslovak radio today.

"A powerful explosion in the Soviet military area of Libava in south-east Czechoslovakia occurred last night, sending a mushroom-shaped orange cloud into the sky and sparking a forest fire," the station said.

Firefighters were rushed to the site but could not gain access, it said.

Analysis of ash samples showed that they were not radioactive and did not contain harmful chemicals, the station said.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Radioactive dust released WORLD</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KIEV: A forest fire near the Chernobyl nuclear plant has released an unknown amount of deadly radioactive dust into the atmosphere, officials admit.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Vadim Grishenko, of the Ukrainian Environment Ministry, said radioactive particles disturbed by the fire would "threaten the outside population".</p><p>The blaze, which started around noon on Tuesday, swept through five abandoned villages and surrounding countryside within 10km of the contaminated site.</p><p> It was fanned by strong winds and took seven hours to bring under control.</p><p> The cause of the fire was thought to be a cigarette discarded by picnickers visiting graves near their former homes.</p><p> The explosion at Chernobyl, which happened 10 years ago this week, scattered fallout over a large part of Europe.</p><p> The extent of radioactivity from the blaze, about 10km northwest of the power plant, was not immediately clear and reports were conflicting.</p><p> But an official said it threatened to spread well beyond the 30km exclusion zone surrounding the plant.</p><p> A Greenpeace spokesman said: "This is clearly a danger to the health of people, and not only in Ukraine." </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Record heat brings dust and fires</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A HAZE which hung over the metropolitan area yesterday was caused by strong north-westerly winds carrying dust from dry paddocks in the north.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The problem was more severe on parts of Eyre Peninsula.</p><p>Southern Yorke Peninsula was buffeted by winds of up to 50km/h which hampered Country Fire Service efforts to battle a fire which began at 12.30pm.</p><p> The blaze destroyed 200ha of scrub, about 5km south of Warooka, before it was brought under control by 60 firefighters late yesterday.</p><p> A 200sq m forest fire in the South-East was contained by Forestry SA firefighters and a CFS firebombing aircraft which dropped foam on the fire.</p><p> It began in a block of 1958 pines near Glencoe nursery at 4pm.</p><p> The CFS, Forestry SA and police were investigating the cause.</p><p> And two bomber aircraft helped CFS crews contain a grass fire near Mylor just before 4pm.</p><p> The cause of the blaze, which was contained to 250sq m, is not known.</p><p> Fire also blackened about 2ha of grassland behind O'Sullivan Beach Football Club late yesterday.</p><p> It was extinguished at 5.50pm by Metropolitan Fire Service crews.</p><p> The temperature in Adelaide peaked at 38.2 degrees at 2.24pm yesterday  making it the hottest March 17 on record.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Qingdao, a port city in east China's Shandong Province, vows to move all local residents who live in shelters into apartment buildings by the end of the century.</p><p>The city started related work in 1993 and by the end of 1997, 18,000 families have moved into new houses.</p><p> XINHUA DAILY TELEGRAPH</p><p> 1. A serious forest fire which broke out in north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region on May 13 had still not been brought under control by yesterday.</p><p> CHINA DAILY</p><p> 1. China and Canada have signed contracts to expand bilateral telecom ties. At a signing ceremony yesterday in Beijing, China's Stone Group clinched a deal to buy US$600,000 worth of TV equipment from ABL Canada Inc., Hunan Water Conservancy Information Center reached a 2.5 million US dollar contract with Harris Communications to build a flood control communication alarm network in the Dongting Lake area, and Gansu Posts and Telecommunications Bureau planned to spend US$4 million to purchase a point-to-point microwave system from SR Telecom Inc.</p><p> (XIC)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SR8-NVT0-0048-T3BJ-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="199"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. In the past two weeks, the fire has killed more than 200 people and made 50,000 homeless in Heilongjiang province. The Government said men and material were pouring into the area, including 300 men with 18 pieces of artillery and 10,000 shells which can be fired at clouds to try to create artificial rain. The Chinese Air Force is flying in relief donated by the JapaneseRed Cross. Floods are sweeping Guangdong province of south China leaving 63 dead and 33,000 homes destroyed. Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BUSHFIRE RAGES IN ISRAEL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JERUSALEM - Fire whipped by desert winds raged through 1000 hectares of forest on the edge of Jerusalem today, forcing the evacuation of five villages.Twenty-two people were taken to hospital, two in serious condition, after inhaling smoke.</p><p>Smoke drifted over the holy city where a smell of burning filled the air from what state radio described as the worst forest fire for years.Temperatures soared to 37 degrees, a 111-year high for July 2 on the Jaffa coast where Tel Aviv stands.Police closed the main highway to Tel Aviv, causing huge traffic jams, as a thick pall billowed from the mainly pine woods on the Judaean hills.A major communications centre and a television station at Neve Ilan, 10km from Jerusalem, were shut and several houses caught fire.In the village of Shoresh, hotel guests gathered around a swimming pool for safety before being rescued.Firemen appealed for volunteers to help bring the blaze under control.- AFPEND OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>EXODUS: ORTHODOX JEWS WALK TO SAFETY AFTER BEING EVACUATED FROM NEVE IIAN WHERE SEVERAL HOUSES CAUGHT urn:contentItem:49K0-21V0-01S8-G1PD-00000-00<published>1986-06-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WEARY TEAMS CONTROL KILLER FIRE AFTER 15 DIE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>COKLEY J</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Weary teams control killer fire after 15 die LISBON._ Portuguese firemen and volunteers appeared yesterday to have won a 24-hour battle against a forest fire which killed 15 people near the northern town of Agueda.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>""The blaze is almost under control," a fire authority official said last night as around 700 firemen, army conscripts and volunteers poured water on to the hillside which at one time was alight along a 30-km front. Twelve firemen and three civilians died in the fire, the worst such tragedy in a country plagued every summer by forest fires. Four of the firemen died when the vehicle they were sheltering under to escape the flames blew up. About 20 villages in the hilly, timber-producing region were evacuated and many farmers lost property and livestock. (Reuter)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Last month, the Kurdish Labor Party kidnapped 10 Germans and released them eight days later.</p><p>AP</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Dr Allen Roberts . . . may have left a trail.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:6F7D-FNN3-RTWS-G25W-00000-00FIRE CHARS TOMBS1994-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:26ZLexisNexisPg. 46FIRE CHARS TOMBS

KEYWORD-HIT Fire chars tombs A YOUNG shepherd has been blamed for a forest fire that tore through a World War I battleground in the Gallipoli peninsula. War monuments and cemeteries holding Turkish and Allied dead were charred and a local fire chief died directing the effort to halt the blaze. ""The shepherd, Ahmet Uysal, 13, lit a fire to roast some corn on the cob, and the fire spread to a field of stubble,'' Forestry Minister Hasan Ekinci said. The boy was detained briefly and released, pending a hearing. The flames damaged some of the 50 military cemeteries and memorials in the area. IN the United States, two battalions of Marines will be sent to help fight fires in the north-west that have destroyed nearly 100 homes and other structures, officials said yesterday. The Marine reinforcements will add 1000 fire fighters to nearly 8000 men and women now battling to contain 30 major fires burning in Washington and Oregon. The fires, which were sparked by lightning strikes last weekend, have blackened more than 52,600ha of tinder-dry timber and grassland.

"Where they used artillery, we will use foam." The site of the fire is covered in flaming mounds of tyres and shredded rubber, shrouded in smoke and surrounded by trenches. The trenches have been dug to capture the run-off from melted tyres and oil is being skimmed off and pumped away by workers wearing gas masks for protection.</p><p> HERALD BUREAU</p><p> END OF Firefighters were battling a forest fire near Mt Beauty in Victoria's north-east as officials revealed that charges were pending against three people following earlier fires in the region.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighters were back-burning to halt the latest fire at Coral Bank near Mt Beauty which broke out when a person was burning off, Natural Resources and Environment Department central fire coordinator Peter Billing said.</p><p>He said the fire had burned through about 35 hectares of forest and was one of three similar burn-off breakaway fires in the region at the weekend.</p><p> The others, at Eskdale and Dodds Bridge, between Mansfield and Benalla, also in the north-east, were under control late yesterday.</p><p> No serious damage was done by the fires in the forest areas.</p><p> But Mr Billing said there had been a total of 18 fires scattered across the state's north-east in the past fortnight and three people would be charged on summons over three of them.</p><p> He said they would be charged with failing to keep a fire they lit under control.</p><p> He said it pointed out how careful people must be when burning off to reduce fire fuel, that the fire did not get out of control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4F20-0048-T0RY-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="200"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P7M-D180-TXN5-R24W-00000-00GREENHOUSE MAY BOOST FIRE RISK1992-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:27ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 4GREENHOUSE MAY BOOST FIRE RISKCATHERINE ARMITAGE Science Writer

Increases in greenhouse gas emissions will cause a greater risk of bushfires, according to a CSIRO computer model.

It found that a doubling of greenhouse gases could lead to Ash Wednesday-type fire risks every summer in parts of Victoria and Western Australia.

The Ash Wednesday fires in 1983, which killed 75 people, were the result of a high-risk combination of factors such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and rainfall level.

These factors are used by the CSIRO's Division of Forestry and Monash University as inputs into a computer model which produces a Forest Fire Danger Index.

Dr Tom Beer, of the CSIRO, has found that relative humidity is the most important factor in estimating fire danger. The amount of moisture in leaf litter on the forest floor determines the fire's ability to generate high temperatures and spread rapidly.

When the model was used to predict what might happen if greenhouse gases doubled, it found the south-west of WA and East Gippsland in Victoria would become drier and more fire prone.

The member for Mulgrave, Mr Menzell, yesterday asked Sir Joh to schedule a Cabinet meeting in the stricken sugar town of Babinda.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>""We are in a dreadful situation up here, with sugar farmers going to the wall, and now the cyclone has just devastated locals," Mr Menzell said. ""It is important that Ministers see at first hand the extent of the calamity so they can devise a workable plan of assistance. ""There is no reason why a country Cabinet meeting could not be scheduled here." A Premier's Department spokesman said that Sir Joh was expected to respond favorably to the request and announce that Cabinet would meet in Babinda early in March. With Parliament sitting for two weeks from next Tuesday, March 3 would be the first available date. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>KILLER FIRE STILL OUT OF CONTROL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SWAYN L</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Killer fire still out of control BEIJING (AAP): Communist China's worst-ever forest fire, which has killed at least 172 people and left 51,000 homeless, raged out of control in the country's north-east today despite efforts to contain it, official reports said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Firebreaks were largely in place on the eastern side of the fire in a remote area of Heilongjiang province near the Sino-Soviet border, state-run evening television news said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire was raging near the city of Tahe, 680km north-west of the Heilongjiang capital of Harbin.</p><p>Tahe, with a population of 100,000, was safe after twice being threatened since the blaze broke out one week ago, the broadcast said.</p><p>The fire has blackened 547,000ha of land and charred 750,000 cubic metres of timber worth 130million yuan ($A49.30million), according to a Forestry Ministry official.</p><p>It also destroyed 431 tractors and trucks, 640,000 square metres of housing, and several bridges and communications facilities worth 276.7million yuan ($A105.36million) an official of the ministry's Fire-Fighting Headquarters said.</p><p>Earlier reports said the fire destroyed three towns, several villages and three railway stations.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XKM-VYB1-DYG0-94PV-00000-00<published>2019-11-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Ulises Izquierdo<br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 27 AAP - Firefighters will take advantage of cooler conditions this week to undertake burning-out works at major fires in remote areas of northeast Victoria.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   It comesafter firefighters last week battled more than 60 blazes across the state and Melbourne registered the hottest November day in a hundred years.<br/>   The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast cooler weather this week for the state, with the Country Fire Authority predicting lower fire risks until Saturday as a result.<br/>   Forest Fire Management Victoria said communities may notice an increase in fire size and smoke as the burning-out works are undertaken.<br/>   ?It?s critically important that we undertake these works now ahead of potentially worsening fire weather,? Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.<br/>   ?The works involve burning out vegetation between the containment line and the fire to reduce the risk of the fire taking a run and potentially impacting communities.?<br/>    There were 17 fires still burning on Tuesday across Victoria's Alpine region, with no communities under threat.<br/>   Many mountain walking tracks were closed to ensure safety of people in the area, and hikers in Victoria's Mount Bogong High Plains were forced to leave the area.<br/>   All of them were ignited last Thursday as a result of dry lightning, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning reported.<br/>    Two new fires also ignited by lightning were reported on Tuesday.<br/>    ?Extreme dryness, erratic winds and difficult terrain have made it challenging for crews to contain these fires,? Mr Kennedy said.<br/>   ?We are fully expecting to be working on these fires for a number of weeks, potentially right up until Christmas and beyond, if we don?t receive significant rainfall.?</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XKM-VYB1-DYG0-94PV-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="300"/><timeReceived>3:31 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:5XS7-WM61-DYG0-92MY-00000-00<published>2019-12-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Aine Fox<br/>   SYDNEY, Dec 18 AAP - Australia has endured its driest spring on record,setting the scene for a devastating bushfire season in which fierce blazes have swept across the country.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   As the nation prepares for a sweltering heatwave and temperatures above 40C, the Bureau of Meteorology on Wednesday confirmed spring was also the second-warmest ever recorded.<br/>   Rainfall was 62 per cent below average, making the spring of 2019 the driest since the previous all-time low in 1967, the BOM said in a special climate statement.<br/>   "The low rainfall added to pre-existing rainfall deficiencies and low soil moisture, exacerbating the meteorologicaland hydrological drought conditions and meaning forest fuels remained dry," the BOM said.<br/>   The average maximum daytime temperature was 2.41C above average, the second-warmest on record behind 2014.<br/>   The country also struggled through record high fire weather danger - as measured using the Forest Fire Danger Index - in each of the country's states and territories during spring.<br/>   "The dangerous fire weather conditions during spring 2019 is consistent with the increasingly severe fireweather seen in many areas of the country, owing to increasing temperatures and reduced cool seasonrainfall," the BOM said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XS7-WM61-DYG0-92MY-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-12-17</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="210"/><timeReceived>1:03 PM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 25 AAP - Hot and dry conditions with maximum temperatures in the low 30s have prompted a Total Fire Ban in Victoria's Northern Country and Mallee districts.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Severe Fire Danger is forecast for both regions, with conditions becoming less extreme towards the south of the state.<br/>   After a Thursday whereMelbourne broke a 100-year-old temperature record for November hitting 40.9C and creeping well into the 40s in the Mallee region and northern country towns, the weekend saw dozens of bushfires blazing across Victoria.<br/>   "This shows us what the risks will be in summer around Victoria, so we still have a long way to go to be ready,"Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said on Thursday.<br/>   Nine bushfire advices were still ongoing on Sunday evening.<br/>   Although no communities were under threat, a bushfire in the Alpine region forced the closure of a number of walking tracks, with hikers advised to leave the area.<br/>   Most of the fires alight during the weekend have been in steep, remote country where the risk of falling trees adds to the difficulty for firefighters to access.<br/>   ?The remote locations of these fires are proving to be challenging for our crews and we fully expect them to burn for a number of weeks as firefighters work hard to contain them," Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume Deputy Chief Fire Officer Aaron Kennedy said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:5XJY-1411-DYG0-930H-00000-00<published>2019-11-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:26Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   MELBOURNE, Nov 23 AAP - Firefighters are hoping mild weekend conditions will help them control blazes caused by lightning in remote patches of forest in Victoria'snortheast.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   About 30 fires were still burning in Victoria on Friday afternoon, 20 of them located in hard-to-reach forested areas of the state's northeast.<br/>   Forest Fire Management Victoria said aircraft including big air tankers from Canberra and Sydney are being used to fight the forest blazes.<br/>   ?The aim is to get on top of them with the milder conditions," the authority's Hume deputy chief fire officerAaron Kennedy said.<br/>   More than 50 firefighting trucks, dozers and other heavy plant were also set to work on Friday to build containment lines and deal with dangerous trees.<br/>   But the remoteness of the fires isn't making their job easy.<br/>   "There is a lot of work to do in very difficult conditions," MrKennedy said.<br/>   More than 150 blazes burned across the state on Thursday,when record-breaking temperatures and strong winds lashed the state.<br/>   The CFA believes lightning or campfires started many of them.<br/>   Melbourne broke a 100-year-old temperature record for November on Thursday, with the mercury hitting 40.9C and creeping well into the 40s in the Mallee region and northern country towns.<br/>   Temperatures cooled on Friday, with emergency services now turning their attention to Monday when the temperature and fire risk are set to rise again, a CFA spokesman told AAP.<br/>   On Monday temperatures are expected to reach the high 30s in the state's north - the driest part of the state - and 32C in central Melbourne.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2019</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5XJY-1411-DYG0-930H-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-11-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="266"/><timeReceived>3:30 AM AEST</timeReceived><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2019 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:4BDR-7T40-00VK-2430-00000-00<published>2004-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:27Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Domestic News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: Goonoo State Forest fire under control</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>SYDNEY, Jan 8</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p/><p nitf:lede="true"> More than 300 firefighters working for days to contain a bushfire in central NSW have brought the blaze under control.</p><p nitf:lede="true">NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman Cameron Wade said cooler temperatures and a change in wind direction had aided fire crews, who for the past three days tirelessly dug containment lines around the blaze.</p><p>The fire, which burned through more than 2000ha of bushland, erupted in the Goonoo State Forest, 25km north east of Dubbo on Monday.</p><p>It came within 7km of the small township of Ballimore, which was placed on high alert yesterday.</p><p>Mr Wade said the fire service would officially declare the fire contained within the next few hours.<br/>    Fire crews would be scaled back but local firefighters would remain for another day or so to "mop up", he said.</p><p>"You could certainly say it is under control," Mr Wade said.</p><p>"They will be an official declaration of containment in the next couple of hours.</p><p>"The only thing that has stopped this fire is basically the volunteer firefighters."</p><p>Meanwhile, NRMA Insurance advised NSW residents to immediate action to protect their properties in case of more fires which could break out due to high temperatures and low humidity forecast this week.</p><p>NRMA Insurance, Head of Product & Underwriting, Graeme Adams also reminded holiday makers who were driving along country roads and through bush land not to throw cigarettes out the window.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Peter Mitchell, AAP US Correspondent<br/>   LOS ANGELES, Dec 3 AAP - Firefighters from provinces across Canada have volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia to help with the bushfire crisis.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Thecrack team has answered Australia's call for help duringwhat's expected to be a dangerous bushfire season.<br/>   Australian officials submitted an official request tothe Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, based in Winnipeg, on Friday and on the weekend, dozens of experienced firefighters from provinces across Canada volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia.<br/>   A group of 21 firefighters was selected and will gather in Vancouver on Tuesday before flying to Sydney for what an expected 38-day deployment.<br/>   "We are pleased to help the people of Australia as they face these devastating fires, especially since Manitoba has been on the receiving end of help from friends and neighbours when wildfires and other natural disasters hit our province," premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, Brian Pallister,said.<br/>   Manitoba is sending two firefighters withBritish Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and Parks Canada contributing 19 others.<br/>   Strong bonds between Manitoba and Australia were built in the most unfortunate circumstances in July and August.<br/>   Canadian teenagers Kam McLeod and Bryer Schmegelsky shot dead Australian tourist Lucas Fowler and his girlfriend Chynna Deese on the side of a British Columbia highway and then fled to Manitoba, sparking a massive manhunt involving the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian military.<br/>   "There's nothing more Manitoban than offering a helping hand when someone else is in need," Mr Pallister said.<br/>   As Australia burns, Canada is heading into winter where temperatures will drop below20 degrees Celsius.<br/>   Theassigned firefighters were selected for their unique skill sets.<br/>   The Canadians will assist with a variety of roles within the incident management team, including planning, aviation and operations.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Peter Mitchell, AAP US Correspondent<br/>   LOS ANGELES, Dec 3 AAP - The Canadians are coming.<br/>   A crack group of Canadian firefighters have answered Australia's call for help to fight devastating bushfires.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Australian officials submitted an official request tothe Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, based in Winnipeg, on Friday and on the weekend, dozens of experienced firefighters from provinces across Canada volunteered to give up Christmas with their families and fly to Australia.<br/>   A group of 21 firefighters were selected from the applicants and will gather in Vancouver on Tuesday before flying to Sydney for what is expected to be a 38-day deployment.<br/>   "We are pleased to help the people of Australia as they face these devastating fires, especially since Manitoba has been on the receiving end of help from friends and neighbours when wildfires and other natural disasters hit our province," premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, Brian Pallister,said.<br/>   Manitoba is sending two firefighters withBritish Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and Parks Canada contributing 19 others.<br/>   Strong bonds between Manitoba and Australia were built in the most unfortunate circumstances in July and August.<br/>   Canadian teenagers Kam McLeod and Bryer Schmegelsky shot dead Australian tourist Lucas Fowler and his girlfriend Chynna Deese on the side of a British Columbia highway and then fled to Manitoba, sparking a massive manhunt involving the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian military.<br/>   "There's nothing more Manitoban than offering a helping hand when someone else is in need," Mr Pallister said.<br/>   As Australia burns, Canada is heading into winter where temperatures will drop below20 degrees Celsius.<br/>   Theassigned firefighters were selected for their unique skill sets.<br/>   The Canadians will assist with a variety of roles within the incident management team, including planning, aviation and operations.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has been killed while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region.<br/>   The man aged in his 60s died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private property so that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters, without revealing the specific cause of the man's death.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and had helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions at the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has been killed while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region.<br/>   The man aged in his 60s died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private property so that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters, without revealing the specific cause of the man's death.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and had helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions at the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received a dumping overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Cheryl Goodenough<br/>   BRISBANE, Nov 15 AAP - Suburbs being built alongside pockets of bush in outer Brisbane have a greater risk of going up in flames than homes in other states, a bushfire building expert believes.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Lower bushfire resilience standards in Queensland mean hundreds of houses could be lost if fire raced through some new Brisbane developments, architect Ian Weir says.<br/>   "It's a disaster waiting to happen," Dr Weir, a founder of the Bushfire Building Council of Australia, told AAP.<br/>   Dr Weir, of the Queensland University of Technology, says homes in the state don't have to be asbushfire resilient as they are required to be in New South Wales and Victoria.<br/>   New developments in suburbs like Yarrabilba, south of Brisbane and Springfield, near Ipswich, backed onto bushland are built to standard but at risk, he said.<br/>   "You would only need a couple of houses ignited and you'd need to evacuate people," he said.<br/>   "Then you'd have houses on fire, igniting neighbouring houses."<br/>   Houses in bushfire prone parts of Victoriahave to be built to a forest fire danger index (FFDI) of 100, while in Queensland the standard is just 40, the lowest in Australia, he said.<br/>   "Nationally the weakest link is in Queensland," Dr Weir said.<br/>   He called on the Queensland Government to raise the state's FFDI.<br/>   He also wants the state to make it mandatory for assessors ofbushfire attack levels (BAL), who determine a building's risk and protection required, to be fully accredited.<br/>   Queensland is the only state that does not require such accreditation.<br/>   A Queensland housing department spokesperson said the government ensured the fire danger rating for the construction of buildings prioritised safety.<br/>   "Given the real threat of bushfires across Queensland communities, this is something we review regularly," the spokesperson said.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has died while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region,bringing the work-related death toll to three in the last six days.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The 69-year-old man died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.<br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private propertyfor the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planningso that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   WorkSafe believes the man lost control of his 4WD utility while driving down a steep embankment and was thrown from his vehicle when it rolled, suffering fatal injuries.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters on Monday.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and has helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east, despite rain and snow in some areas.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions on the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received snowfall overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   The Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Kaitlyn Offer<br/>   MELBOURNE, Dec 2 AAP - A bulldozer operator has died while helping fight a bushfire in Victoria's Gippsland region,bringing the work-related death toll to three in the last six days.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The 69-year-old man died late on Saturday at the fires near Gelantipy, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said on Monday.<br/>   He was working on earth breaks on private propertyfor the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planningso that firefighters could battle a blaze on public land.<br/>   WorkSafe believes the man lost control of his 4WD utility while driving down a steep embankment and was thrown from his vehicle when it rolled, suffering fatal injuries.<br/>   "It's the worst possible day we could have as a team, personally it's just a horrible, hollow feeling," Mr Hardman told reporters on Monday.<br/>   "We've lost somebody that's come to help us and I hope and pray that we don't lose any more people."<br/>   The man was from the East Gippsland region and has helped fire crews in the past.<br/>   Victoria Police are preparing a report for the coroner and WorkSafe is also investigating.<br/>   Fires continue to burn in Victoria's east, despite rain and snow in some areas.<br/>   Incident controller Peter Brick said while there had been cooler conditions on the weekend, the underlying drought means fire activity could quickly ramp up when the warmer weather returns.<br/>   "We can't reiterate enough how dry the land is across Gippsland at the moment," he told reporters.<br/>   "Now's the time to prepare."<br/>   While fires burn, parts of the state have been dumped with snow in a chilly start to summer.<br/>   Falls Creek received snowfall overnight and on Monday morning, as did Mount Buller and Mount Hotham.<br/>   The Great Alpine Road between Harrietville and Hotham had to be cleared of snow on Monday morning and drivers were warned more was expected to come.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">AAPNEW-</dc:identifier><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>   SYDNEY, Sept 16 AAP - Conditions are expected to improve for NSW firefighters after strong winds caused "erratic" fire behaviour and saw two major blazes flare up in the state's north.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   The NSW Rural Fire Service issued emergency warnings for one bushfire at Drake and another east of Glen Innes in the Brother State Forest on Monday afternoon.<br/>   The Brother State Forest blaze was ultimately downgraded in the evening.<br/>   RFS inspector Ben Shepherd said strengthening northwesterlies had caused some "quite erratic fire behaviour" on Monday, but conditions should be more favourable on Tuesday.<br/>   "The bureau has indicated there is the chance now of some thunderstorm activity - which may result in some lightning - so we will be watching that carefully," he said.<br/>   On Monday afternoon, RFS deputy commissioner Rob Rogers said the Drake blaze was threatening properties in the Drake and Red Rock areas and they had advised residents to "prepare for fire impact".<br/>   "It's causing fire crews a lot of problems today," he told ABC News.<br/>   The 16,000ha Brother State Forest fire was given a Watch and Act alert after the threat to homes eased on Monday night, but the blaze was still burning out of control.<br/>   Several schools in the vicinity of both fires will be closed on Tuesday.<br/>   The flare-ups come after fire conditions across NSW eased on Sunday, with firefighters gaining the upper hand on a number of blazes.<br/>   But Monday's weather, including strong wind warnings up and down the NSW coast, caused fresh headaches.<br/>   Fifty-seven bush and grass fires were burning in the afternoon and about 20 were not contained.<br/>   Mr Rogers said a 92,000ha bushfire in Bees Nest near Armidale was "nowhere near contained" but was not threatening properties.<br/>   Most regions of NSW have been given a low-moderate fire danger rating on Tuesday.<br/>   However, New England and the Northern Slopes face a very high fire danger, while the North Western and Far North Coast regions have been given a high fire danger rating.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5X6X-6WS1-DYG0-929B-00000-00<published>2019-10-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:04:26Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"><pre xml:space="preserve">  <br/>Liza Kappelle<br/>   BRISBANE, Oct 7 AAP - Firefighters are urging Queenslanders to beware of dangerous fire conditions as they battle bushfires in sweltering conditions.<br/>   Dry and windy conditions are pushing temperatures in some parts of the state up to 12C above average for October on Monday, the Bureau of Meteorology says.</pre></p><p><pre xml:space="preserve"><br/>   Brisbane is expected to reach 34 degrees while further inland, at Esk, Ipswich, Laidley and Gatton, 40 degrees is expected.<br/>   Rural Fire Service acting director Wayne Waltisbuhl says there are about 15 fires burning across Queensland on Monday.<br/>   The two most significant are at Glen Rock State Forest, south of Gatton, and Swanfels, north-north east of Warwick.<br/>   The Glen Rock State Forest fire started a week ago from a lightning strike, MrWaltisbuhl says.<br/>   Aircraft are water-bombing to slow down the blaze so ground crews can try to contain the fire which has come out of inaccessible country to grazing land.<br/>   "Its going to be pretty tough because by about midday/early afternoon the bad weather conditions are going to impact," he told AAP.<br/>   On Monday morning it was burning in the vicinity of Cole Gully Road in the Lefthand Branch area.<br/>   Severe fire danger conditions are forecast for the bone dry Darling Downs and Granite Belt, and Maranoa and Warrego districts.<br/>   There is the potential for pockets of extreme fire danger conditions in the southern, forested parts of these districts, the Bureau of Meteorology says.<br/>   The fire at Swanfels was also started by lightning strike and fire crews hope to contain it as much as possible before more dangerous conditions set in.<br/>   Mr Waltisbuhl says the fires of most concern, however, are those that haven't started yet.<br/>   He is urging Queenslanders to have fire plans ready to enact, including grab bags with things to take in an emergency.<br/>   Firefighters are also urging people to be careful of sparking fires, with temperaturesexpected to remain high in the southeast until Wednesday.<br/>   Queensland has had a destructive start to the bushfire season with massive fires forcing evacuations, with the worst in the Scenic Rim, Sunshine Coast and Granite Belt regions.</pre></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FRONTPAGE</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Brendan Wrigley</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Branches of the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning will undergo another name change in the coming months, as forest firefighters take on the Forest Fire Management brand.</p><p nitf:lede="true">DELWP vehicles and uniforms will be re-branded under the name change, while new personal protective clothing will also be labelled with the new name.</p><p>The change comes after a review into the Lancefield-Cobaw fire, where an out of control burn off sparked a 4000 hectare fire bushfire. </p><p>While the DELWP refused to disclosed how much the roll out of the new title would cost, a DELWP spokesperson said the department would take 'all necessary steps' to ensure costs were kept to a minimum.</p><p>'The development of a brand for forest firefighters that is recognisable and long lasting was one of the recommendations from the independent investigation into the Lancefield-Cobaw fire.'</p><p>The Courier understands the branch name change will allow firefighters to remain under the same title if the department was to again change names in the future.</p><p>The move comes after the department name change from Department of Environment and Primary Industries (DEPI) to DELWP in February 2015 following the change of state government.</p><p>Ballarat MP Joshua Morris said while it was important forest firefighters were recognised for their work , it was important the money went towards helping to fight fires.</p><p>'The recommendations for this name change is a direct result of Labor's ongoing restructuring and rebranding of government departments.'</p><p>'We always want to see government money well spent.'</p><p>The DELWP is also proposing a major internal restructure which will create a new Forest Fire and Regions group.</p><p>The new group would take elements from the current Fire and Emergency Management Division and other parts of its current Land, Fire and Environment Group and the Regional Services Group.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
